metadata.title: Women and Labour in Late Colonial India: The Bengal Jute Industry

relevance.topic: Labor displacement due to technological change in the Bengal Jute Industry
relevance.relevance: The study examines the decline of women workers in the jute industry from 25% to 2% of the workforce, highlighting the impact of technological and social changes on labor displacement.

design.sample_characteristics: Focus on women workers in the Bengal jute industry, primarily widows and deserted wives, during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

dependent_variables.displaced: Women workers declined from 25% to 2% of the workforce.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Women were increasingly excluded from the workforce and concentrated in lower-paid jobs.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Women were paid less than men, and their work was considered supplementary.

key_themes: Impact of technological change on employment
text_fragments: Women workers in the jute industry declined from 25% to 2% of the workforce.
The industry increasingly employed men due to technological changes and social perceptions.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes how technological advancements and social perceptions led to the marginalization of women in the jute industry.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of industrial expansion followed by economic depression in the 1930s.
historical_context.institutional_context: Colonial labor policies and social norms influenced employment practices.

outcomes.main_findings: The study finds that technological advancements and social perceptions led to the marginalization and displacement of women workers in the jute industry.
outcomes.conclusions: Technological changes and social norms significantly contributed to the decline of women workers in the jute industry.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The displacement of women workers reinforced gender inequalities and affected their economic independence.
